answers.answer: The shortness of breath is due to the anemia that we get...it is DREADFUL and just walking a few feet can seem impossible. I remember that feeling well.It's not "wheezing" it's more like your lungs being just too tired to do the breathing.Have you had a CBC to check where your hemoglobin stands? That number is CRUCIAL to keep an eye on during treatment.
What about having really cold feet during treatment?
Check 5/16 thread 'Post Treatment Problems' for comments/q's from merlino.  You and she are in similar boats.

Actually, tx resolved my blood sugar issues.  Going into tx was on lower doses of insulin and pre-tx A1C was 13.(avg glucose of about 350). When I got to undetectable at week 12 blood sugar normalized and taken off insulin.  Today, 6 months post tx, sugar in normal ranges A1c about 6.3 and no insulin. Funny thing is I relapsed.  Hard to make sense out of hcv.  Although I expect that if I was to staff off tx sugar would go wonky again.  But I expect to go back to tx in a couple of months.  There is a connecttion between diabetes and hcv, moreso with more liver damage
I wanted to know how bad did the tx effect your blood sugar.I had to up my insulin.things working out now

Cold feet in more ways than one. During tx I had sort of tingling and coolness in the feet, like blood flow wasn't getting there - like a tourniquet might restrict flow. This is wierd, but it also felt like the pads of my feet, behind the toes, was swollen too, but it was not visibly noticeable - just a strange feeling. Resolved after tx a couple of months. Originally though it was due to diabetes and blood sugar probalem

Take a look at the 5/17 thread 'How is Hepc measured..', Mike's attachment in c16. You'll need to do a quick register to read.  Blood sugar abnormalities are common with hcv - I belive that's the origination of mine.  The article makes sense to me in that my liver condition makes me a little more prone to BS issues. My concern is that I had diabetes, tx seemed to resolve it, now I've relapsed.   Stinkin' disease.
